VodkaPundit, Part Deux.

Cameron had an interesting post yesterday about an offer that was made to Rogan:
Rumble, an alternative to YouTube, has offered podcast host Joe Rogan $100 million to ditch Spotify for their platform instead.
Between the 74,000 television streaming services — those things multiply like Tribbles — and all the podcasts, there aren’t enough hours in the day to keep up with even a fraction of the content.

“How about you bring all your shows to Rumble, both old and new, with no censorship, for 100 million bucks over four years?”
“This is our chance to save the world.
His latest book, Straight Outta Feelings, is a humorous exploration of how the 2016 election made him enjoy politics more than he ever had before.
While I am always preaching about conservatives being engaged in pop culture I have to admit that there is a lot of stuff that isn’t on my radar.
Given the success that the cancel lunatics have had in the social media era, it’s not a stretch to think that the company will eventually cave.
There is also the fact that exiting Spotify might let the rage mob think that they’ve scored a win, even if Rogan doesn’t take a financial hit.

And yes, this is totally legit.”
I’ve been saying for a couple of weeks that Rogan should leave Spotify and start his own podcasting platform.
This current drama surrounding him and Spotify is turning me into a huge Rogan fan merely because so many of his haters are awful people.

The major tech sites have been publishing articles about canceling Spotify subscriptions almost daily for a few weeks.

Enough Already With the Leftist Talking Heads
This nonsense again.
A letter from Rumble CEO Chris Pavlovski explains that Rogan would be offered a creative space without censorship.
Obviously, I’ve been aware of Joe Rogan for a long time because he’s a comedian who did very well for himself.
The only way to kneecap cancel culture is to make sure they don’t have any victories, especially bigger ones.
When not being a reclusive writer, Kruiser has had the honor of entertaining U.S. troops all over the world.
Spotify hasn’t been swayed by the cancel mob yet and that just seems to be filling their diapers even more.
For the moment, it’s possible to be Team Rogan and Team Spotify, and the longer that lasts, the better.

So we’d like to offer you 100 million reasons to make the world a better place,” the letter states.
The optics are even worse given the struggles most people have endured the past couple of years.
While the Rumble offer is intriguing, Spotify should be commended for hanging on this long.
I only just became aware of Rumble a few weeks ago and know very little about the company.

The arrogance would be appalling under the best of circumstances.
Nothing against Rogan, I just don’t listen to a lot of podcasts.
